items.title: All Ralph variants share INV-003
items.content:
INV-003: External state > internal memory
Whether using files, prd.json, Linear, or SQLite - state lives OUTSIDE the model. This is the common DNA that makes "fresh context" work.

items.title: The irreducible core across all variants
items.content:
while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude; done
Everything else is optimization around this fundamental loop. Original Ralph IS the minimal pattern. Other variants add scaffolding.

items.title: Ralph Family = Unix Philosophy
items.content:
Original: cat/grep (do one thing well)
Production: make (structured automation)
Marathon: CI/CD pipeline (full lifecycle)
Lisa: requirements.txt (specification)
Zeroshot: code review (independent validation)

items.title: Ryan Carson: The 14-iteration feature
items.content:
Untangle Legal Agent, Income Upsert Tool. 6 user stories, ran overnight.
          14 iterations, ~$10-15, 2 hours autonomous. "Learnings compound.
          By story 10, Ralph knew our patterns."

items.title: How to read the variant spectrum
items.content:
Beginner: "What's the difference?" → Complexity level
Intermediate: "Which is best?" → Depends on use case
Advanced: "When to combine?" → Lisa + execution variant
Staff: "What's unsolved?" → Optimal progression timing

items.title: Simplicity vs Capability
items.content:
Original: Fastest setup, highest rework risk
Production: Moderate both
Marathon: Slower setup, lower rework
Zeroshot: Slowest setup, lowest rework

No free lunch. Choose based on your constraint.

items.title: Why Production Ralph needs story sizing
items.content:
ROOT: Context window is finite (~200K tokens)
→ Each iteration must be self-contained
→ Tasks must complete in one context window
→ "2-3 sentence" rule for story sizing
→ Story too big = context overflow = failure

items.title: What if workers validated their own work?
items.content:
You'd have Traditional Ralph: Worker writes code → Worker checks its own work.
Why this fails: Self-validation is biased. Workers know what they MEANT to do, can rationalize poor implementation.
Revealed: Zeroshot's blind validation removes this bias.

items.title: When does Marathon's overhead pay off?
items.content:
Single feature: Marathon overhead exceeds benefit
3+ features: Tests compound, verify phase pays off
Full project: Full SDLC is invaluable

Don't use Marathon for one-off tasks. Use for sustained development.

items.title: Lisa + Production Ralph
items.content:
Works? Yes - this is the recommended combination
Why: Lisa ensures PRD quality, Production executes reliably
The synergy: Lisa's JSON output is directly compatible with prd.json

items.title: Molly Cantillon: Jmail with 18M users
items.content:
Built overnight with Ralph loops. Production-scale email service.
          Proof that Ralph works for real applications, not just demos.

items.title: How to use the decision tree
items.content:
Beginner: Follow the tree literally
Intermediate: Consider combinations (Lisa + X)
Advanced: Factor in team context, existing tooling
Staff: Question whether Ralph is even the right family

items.title: If Ralph isn't right for your use case
items.content:
Need parallelism? → CC Mirror
Need factory-scale? → Gas Town
Debugging, not building? → Single Claude session
Content, not code? → Ralph Wiggum Marketer

items.title: If you skip Lisa when specs are unclear
items.content:
IF: Skip planning, jump to Production Ralph
THEN: Stories are vague or too large
THEN: Tasks fail repeatedly
THEN: You spend time debugging PRD, not building
FINALLY: Total time exceeds Lisa investment

items.title: When Original → Production is worth it
items.content:
1-2 tasks: Original is fine
3-5 tasks: Production's story sizing helps
5+ tasks: Production's AGENTS.md compounds

THE INFLECTION: ~3 tasks per feature
If you're regularly doing 3+ tasks, upgrade.

items.title: How verification quality degrades
items.content:
Self-validation (Original): Biased but fast
Criteria-based (Production): Better, depends on criteria quality
Mandatory phases (Marathon): Thorough, slower
Blind validators (Zeroshot): Most honest, most expensive

items.title: State persistence across variants
items.content:
All variants externalize state, but in different forms:
Original: Files (PROMPT.md, progress.txt)
Production: JSON (prd.json, AGENTS.md)
Marathon: Linear API (issues, state file)
Zeroshot: SQLite (messages, cluster history)

items.title: UNSOLVED: Cross-variant state transfer
items.content:
The question: Can learnings from Production Ralph inform Marathon Ralph?
Why it's hard: State formats differ. No common schema.
Current practice: Manual migration, AGENTS.md as bridge.

items.title: API Cost vs Human Time vs Rework Risk
items.content:
Original: $ API, 1-2h human, Medium-High rework
Zeroshot: $$$ API, 0.5h human, Very Low rework

THE DILEMMA: Cheaper API = more human time + more rework. Which do you optimize for?

items.title: At scale, validation costs compound
items.content:
Small project: Zeroshot overhead seems excessive
Large project: Each caught bug saves downstream debugging

THRESHOLD: ~10 features/month
At this scale, Zeroshot's cost is offset by reduced defects.

items.title: Cost tiers = CI/CD tiers
items.content:
Original: Manual testing (fast, risky)
Production: Unit tests (balanced)
Marathon: CI pipeline (thorough)
Zeroshot: Code review + CI (comprehensive)

items.title: How to estimate costs
items.content:
Beginner: Use reference table as-is
Intermediate: Factor in retry rates (+50-100%)
Advanced: Factor in model tier (Opus = 3-5x Sonnet)
Staff: Factor in human opportunity cost

items.title: When to migrate vs stay
items.content:
Week 1: Migration feels like overhead
Week 4: Benefits start showing
Week 12: Can't imagine going back

Don't judge migration value at week 1. Commit for at least a month.

items.title: Why Marathon requires Linear
items.content:
ROOT: Marathon needs cross-session persistence
→ Can't use files (too fragile for 6-phase SDLC)
→ Needs structured issue tracking
→ Linear provides: project creation, state, bug tickets
→ No Linear = No Marathon

items.title: If you migrate too fast
items.content:
IF: Jump from Original to Zeroshot without learning
THEN: Don't understand underlying principles
THEN: Can't debug when things go wrong
FINALLY: Blame the tool instead of your understanding

items.title: Ralph + Git Worktrees
items.content:
Works? Yes - true parallelization
Why: Isolated filesystems, separate git histories
The danger: Watch API rate limits, coordinate shared resources
Recommendation: Use for independent features only

items.title: Ralph in Gas Town = Worker threads
items.content:
YOU = Mayor (orchestrator)
Refinery = Task decomposer
Ralph instances = Worker threads (Dogs)
Deacon = Integration/QA gate

Each Ralph is a stateless worker in a factory.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Optimal multi-model mix
items.content:
The question: Which model for which Zeroshot role?
Current practice: Haiku for conductor, Opus for planner, Sonnet for worker
Open: Optimal validator model, cross-provider mixing

items.title: snarktank/ralph: 4.9k stars
items.content:
Production Ralph's GitHub repo is the most starred Ralph implementation.
          Proof of community adoption and production validation.
          Over 100 contributors, active development.

items.title: What if you used Marathon for quick prototypes?
items.content:
You'd get: Tests for throwaway code, Linear overhead for experiments
Why this fails: 6-phase SDLC for code you'll delete
Revealed: Marathon optimizes for longevity, not speed

items.title: Beyond the Ralph family
items.content:
Need team coordination? → Gas Town factory
Need real-time parallelism? → CC Mirror
Need domain-specific agents? → Personal Panopticon
Need content generation? → Ralph Wiggum Marketer

items.title: The Optimal Progression Dilemma
items.content:
Fast track: Jump to advanced variants (more capability, steeper learning)
Gradual: Progress through levels (slower, deeper understanding)

Recommendation: Gradual unless time-pressured. Understanding beats capability you can't debug.

items.title: When to stop upgrading variants
items.content:
0-3 features/month: Original or Production sufficient
3-10 features/month: Lisa + Production sweet spot
10+ features/month: Consider Marathon or Zeroshot

THE INFLECTION: ~10 features/month
Beyond this, advanced variants' overhead is justified.
